meanings.definition: To disinherit someone from a will or inheritance.
meanings.sent1: She decided to disherit her nephew from her will.
meanings.sent2: The old man chose to disherit his ungrateful son.
meanings.sent3: The cat playfully threatened to disherit the dog from its toy.
meanings.sent4: The storm seemed to disherit the land of its greenery.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's unfair grading system could disherit hardworking students of their success.

meanings.definition: To exclude someone from receiving an inheritance.
meanings.sent1: The wealthy uncle wanted to disherit his greedy niece.
meanings.sent2: It is not uncommon for families to disherit distant relatives.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel tried to disherit the birds from the bird feeder.
meanings.sent4: The dark clouds threatened to disherit the town of sunlight.
meanings.sent5: The strict rules could disherit many from enjoying the benefits.

meanings.definition: To deprive someone of their rightful inheritance.
meanings.sent1: The evil stepmother sought to disherit Cinderella from her rightful share.
meanings.sent2: Legal battles can sometimes disherit rightful heirs from their inheritance.
meanings.sent3: The misbehaving student joked that the teacher might disherit them from recess.
meanings.sent4: The harsh winter could disherit the animals of their food source.
meanings.sent5: The unexpected turn of events could disherit many from their anticipated wealth.
